title: Cat. 10  Thorn Extractor, 1906
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Thorn Extractor  
Collioure, 1906; cast Paris, 1953  
Bronze; edition 6/10; 20.2 × 14 × 15.2 cm (7 15/16 × 5 1/2 × 6 in.)  
Signed and numbered: 6/10 HM (on back)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Ruth Stanton Family Foundation, 2008.189

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse initially made the model of Thorn Extractor in a soft material, either in clay or possibly a commercial material such as Plasticine. A two-part plaster mold would have been made from the model, often by a professional mold maker. The model would almost certainly have been damaged or destroyed when the mold was removed. From this waste mold a plaster of the sculpture was then cast, which, in turn, was then used to make a carefully created piece mold or a flexible gelatin mold. From one of the plaster versions yet another mold would have been made, in this case, a gelatin mold for lost-wax casting. The bronze edition of Thorn Extractor was lost-wax cast by the C. Valsuani foundry. Numerous mold lines are visible on the surface. It has a dark-brown patina, lightening to a medium-golden-brown tone. X-ray images show evidence of the casting and of repairs.

Incised: 6/10 HM (on back) (fig. 10.1).

Bronze (an alloy of primarily copper and tin). A sample was taken for [glossary:LA-ICP MS] analysis (fig. 10.2).

Lost-wax cast.

C. Valsuani foundry, Paris.

Dark brown, lightening to a medium-golden-brown tone on larger flat areas. XRF analysis of the surface indicates that the patina contains chromium, a characteristic of many Valsuani patinas.

The core material is white with a granular component (fig. 10.3). There are numerous mold lines, the most prominent of which are at the proper left side of the supporting element, the proper left back corner, the back of the hips extending into the supporting element, and across the proper right leg, extending into the supporting element (fig. 10.4).

X-rays of the object (fig. 10.5) show a few round plugs, repairs of casting flaws done, likely while still at the Valsuani foundry. There also appears to be a repair in the back of the supporting element in which an irregular piece of bronze has been incorporated into a gap. This repair corresponds to a slight depression in the outside surface.

The piece was lightly cleaned of grime in 2013 by Art Institute conservators. A small amount of microcrystalline wax was added to dull areas.

The sculpture is in sound condition. Grayish-white material, possibly investment, is visible in low areas of the face and neck and, to a lesser extent, elsewhere on the sculpture. There are a few very tiny bright scratches.  
Suzanne R. Schnepp

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Estate of the artist, from Nov. 3, 1954.

By descent to his son, Jean Matisse (Jan. 10, 1899–Dec. 10, 1976), Paris, after Nov. 3, 1954–Dec. 10, 1976.

By descent to his son, Gérard Matisse (Apr. 7, 1931–May 4, 2006), Dec. 10, 1976–May 4, 2006.

Estate of Gérard Matisse, May 4, 2006–by Feb. 15, 2008.

Purchased by the Ruth Stanton Foundation, New York, by Feb. 15, 2008–June 9, 2008.

Given to the Art Institute of Chicago, June 9, 2008.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Collioure, France, Château Royal de Collioure, Matisse et ses amis: Collioure 1905–1906, June 18–Oct. 9, 2005, no cat. no. (ill.), as Tireur d’épine, Collioure 1906.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Claude Duthuit and Wanda de Guébriant, Henri Matisse: Catalogue raisonné de l’oeuvre sculpté (C. Duthuit, 1997), p. 66, cat. 26, no. 6, as Tireur d’épine, Thorn Extractor–Spinario, Figure Drawing a Thorn, Collioure, 1906 [cast 1953].

Étienne Sabench, Matisse et ses amis: Collioure, 1905–1906 (Association des Amis du Musée de Collioure, 2005), p. 38 (ill.), as Tireur d’épine, Collioure 1906.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscription  
Location: back of base  
Method: incised  
Content: 6/10 HM (fig. 10.6)

Inscription  
Location: proper left side of the base, toward the front  
Method: incised  
Content: CIRE / C. VALSUANI / PERDUE [in rectangle with rounded corners] (fig. 10.7)

Performed using a Varian model ICP-MS New Wave UP 213 laser. Analysis was performed by Monica Ganio, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois, at the Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago.

Performed with a portable Bruker Tracer III-V energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometer with an X-ray tube equipped with a rhodium (Rh) transmission target and thermoelectrically cooled Ag-free SiPIN detector.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Claude Duthuit and Wanda de Guébriant list multiple variations of this title: Tireur d’épine, Thorn Extractor–Spinario, and Figure Drawing a Thorn; in Claude Duthuit and Wanda de Guébriant, Henri Matisse: Catalogue raisonné de l’oeuvre sculpté (C. Duthuit, 1997), p. 66, cat. 26.

Clay must be kept damp to avoid cracking as it dries; Plasticine is formulated to be nondrying.

Modern sculpture alloys are usually alloys of copper, tin and zinc, with lead added to improve pouring.

Analyzed by Monica Ganio, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois. Analysis was conducted at the Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago; see Ganio, ICP-OES analysis report, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

For an explanation of the lost-wax casting in the context of Matisse, see Ann Boulton, “The Making of Matisse’s Bronzes,” in Dorothy Kosinski, Jay McKean Fisher, and Steven Nash, Matisse: Painter as Sculptor, exh. cat. (Baltimore Museum of Art/Dallas Museum of Art/Nasher Sculpture Center/Yale University Press, 2007), pp. 73–97.

Suzanne Schnepp, XRF results, 2007, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

Suzanne Schnepp, treatment note, 2013, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

Franck Giraud, of Giraud, Pissarro, Segalot, to Stephanie D’Alessandro, email, May 21, 2011; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Modern and Contemporary Art, Art Institute of Chicago. Henri Matisse died November 3, 1954.

Franck Giraud, of Giraud, Pissarro, Segalot, to Stephanie D’Alessandro, email, May 21, 2011; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Modern and Contemporary Art, Art Institute of Chicago.

Franck Giraud, of Giraud, Pissarro, Segalot, to Stephanie D’Alessandro, email, May 21, 2011; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Modern and Contemporary Art, Art Institute of Chicago. Gérard’s father, Jean Matisse, died on December 10, 1976.

Franck Giraud, of Giraud, Pissarro, Segalot, to Stephanie D’Alessandro, email, May 21, 2011; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Modern and Contemporary Art, Art Institute of Chicago. Gérard Matisse died on May 4, 2006.

Ruth S. Stanton to Douglas Druick, Feb. 15, 2008; and Board of Trustees meeting minutes, June 9, 2008, p. 5; photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Modern and Contemporary Art, Art Institute of Chicago.

Board of Trustees meeting minutes, June 9, 2008, p. 5; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Modern and Contemporary Art, Art Institute of Chicago.
